subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th September 2019: Stocks subdued despite progressive trade developments
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries lower, Dollar lower, Crude lower
  • REAR VIEW: Trump would consider an interim trade deal; ECB hawks voice resentment; Strong US retail sales; Financials boosted from steepening yield curve
  • NEXT WEEK: MON: Chinese Industrial Production, Retail Sales TUE: RBA Minutes, German ZEW, US Industrial Production,WED: EZ CPI, FOMC & BCB THU: Norges Bank, BoE, BoJ, SNB, and SARB, CBRT Minutes. Click here for full Week in Focus.

US MARKET WRAP 13th September 2019: Stocks subdued despite progressive trade developments

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries lower, Dollar lower, Crude lower

* REAR VIEW: Trump would consider an interim trade deal; ECB hawks voice resentment; Strong US retail sales; Financials boosted from steepening yield curve

* NEXT WEEK: MON: Chinese Industrial Production, Retail Sales TUE: RBA Minutes, German ZEW, US Industrial Production,

WED: EZ CPI, FOMC & BCB THU: Norges Bank, BoE, BoJ, SNB, and SARB, CBRT Minutes. Click here for full Week in Focus.

 

* US-CHINA: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, on Thursday evening, said he was hopeful progress will be made in trade talks, adding that Huawei is not a pawn in them. In reference to the prior day’s reports, US President Trump stated he would rather get a whole deal with China, instead of an interim deal. However, Trump added he ‘guesses’ he would consider an interim deal. In a recent bout of positive trade developments over the last few days, further concessions have been discussed, FT reports. The reports state that administration officials in the US have been debating reducing, or even removing some tariffs, on China to ease trade tensions in order to pave the way for a ‘ceasefire’. Also adding to the developments, China mouthpiece Hu Xijin announced, based on what he knows, the Chinese government is encouraging companies to purchases certain US farm products, including soybean & pork, which will also be exempted from additional tariffs. This will please Trump as it will help US farmers, whose vote he will rely on in the upcoming 2020 election. Xinhua confirmed reports by stating that the China State Council will exclude some agricultural goods, including soybeans and pork, from additional tariffs.

* ECB: Commentary after yesterday’s rate decision display the hawks have shown concern regarding the decisions made, Austria’s Holzman stated yesterday’s decision was a major push back and Netherlands’ Knot said the measures are not in line with the economic situation and that the EZ is growing at full capacity, dismissing QE as the right instrument. In an interview with Bild, Germany’s Weidmann also agreed, stating the ECB went overboard with its stimulus package, adding he will make sure hikes are not delayed for too long. The comments from these nations are not too surprising given the hawkish nature of the members. Reminder, source reports yesterday stated the Dutch, French, Austrians, Germans and Estonians opposed the move to restart QE. Elsewhere, Slovenia’s Vasle said he expects low growth of activity and prices to continue in the upcoming months, adding ECB could introduce new policy tools if it is needed. Of note for European banks, the ECB stated Eurozone banks are to repay EUR 31.8bln worth of TLTRO 2 funds earlier than initially planned.

* CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: PREVIEWING ECB, CBRT; REVIEWING PBOC, BOC, RBA, RIKSBANK, CBR. To download the report, please click here

* US RETAIL SALES: US Retail sales for the month of August beat expectations, coming in at 0.4% M/M vs forecasts for 0.2%, while July’s figure was also revised 0.1% higher. The National Retail Federation stated that “consumer attitudes about the economy indicate some retreating optimism” but consumer spending remained resilient and continued to be a key contributor to US growth. On the breakdown, auto sales and building materials made a strong contribution, while gasoline station sales was the main drag, reflecting the recent decline in prices. The data points to another decent contribution to GDP as the control reading continued to increase at 0.3%, albeit at a slower pace than July, which was revised lower by 0.1 ppt to 0.9%; ING see Q3 GDP growth on course to print just above 2%. In summary, ING say the report highlights the point that “while not everything is rosy in the US economy, overall it remains some way off recession and market expectations for aggressive Federal Reserve policy stimulus may be misplaced”. When taken in the context of a yesterday’s better than expected CPI inflation print, “it takes the already remote prospect of a 50bp rate cut next week firmly off the table” says the bank. Moreover, they expect the Fed to stick with its “mid-cycle adjustment” mantra when they cut rates by 25bp next week.

* UNI OF MICHIGAN SURVEY: Headline sentiment slightly beat expectations, printing 92 for September, vs forecasts for 90.9 and increasing from the prior 89.8. Expectations beat by 0.4 pts at 82.4 and rising from the prior 79.9, conditions also rose however fell slightly short of expectations, printing 106.9, consensus was for 107. The rise in expectations and conditions however were only slight and therefore only slightly pare back the drop seen last month. Pantheon note that despite the jobless claims remaining at a cycle low, which is a driver for the conditions index, the metric is clearly trending lower, presumably due to the trade war. The desk highlights that Expectations are elevated in relation to movements in both the stock market and gas prices, which are usual drivers for the index. On inflation expectations, the 1 year ticked up 1ppt to 2.8% and the 5-year declined to 2.3% (Prev. 2.6%), both within recent ranges. Pantheon expect both to rise over the next few months as the tariffs are passed through. 

* GEOPOLITICS: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said European companies will be targeted by US sanctions if they operate in Iran. EU states also reiterated their concern with Iran’s divergence from the Nuclear Deal on Friday. Elsewhere, a US Navy Warship conducted a "Freedom of Navigation" in the South China Sea, similar to that it exercised on August 28th. Turkish President Erdogan said he is to discuss with US President Trump the purchase of the US Patriot missile defence system, that he will meet with Trump at the UN, and to which he said his personal bond with Trump could overcome potential US sanctions.

* WTI (V9) SETTLES USD 0.24 LOWER AT USD 54.85/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLES USD 0.16 LOWER AT USD 60.22/BBL: Energy prices are subdued to conclude the week as desks note continued concern over a “daunting” OPEC supply glut, as flagged by the IEA on Thursday. There is also the overhang of the OPEC+ JMMC meeting where energy analysts at Citigroup highlight the scepticism over pledges from non-compliant members to fall in-line, “this focus and the price action together suggest and reinforce a dominant bearish sentiment.” Similar to the EIA and OPEC, Barclays lowered its oil demand growth forecasts by 200k BPD in both 2019 and 2020 to 800k BPD and 1.3mln BPD, respectively; Barclays also lowered its Brent average price forecast to USD 65/bbl and USD 69/bbl in 2019 and 2020, respectively. The latest Baker Hughes rig count showed US oil drillers cutting rigs for the fourth week in a row: oil rigs -5 at 733, gas rigs -7 at 153, total rigs -12 at 886.

* US T-NOTES (Z9) SETTLES 27+ TICKS LOWER AT 128-18+. Yields continued their “back-up” to end the week amid further signs of progress on the US-China trade front. The large moves lower in the TPLEX came after the latest University of Michigan Survey, where losses extended as the Europeans closed up for the weekend. Treasuries were also taking some cues from EGB selling, as participants digest the latest ECB tiering system which gives leeway to banks to reallocate their reserves at the ECB at the tiered rate instead of in negative yielding government debt. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin again stated that the US is looking whether there is proper demand for a 50-year bond and that the treasury will consider 100-year bonds. At settlement the curve had bear steepened significantly with yields up over 10bp in the belly to long end of the curve.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -0.1% at 3007, NASDAQ-100 -0.3% at 7893, Dow Jones 0.1% at 27220

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.2%, Consumer Staples -0.8%, Energy 0.8%, Financials 0.8%, Health Care -0.1%, Industrials 0.5%, Information Technology -0.7%, Materials 1.1%, Telecommunication Services -0.1%, Utilities -0.6%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) weighed on indices after a PT cut at Goldman on EPS concerns from the latest TV+ trial bundle; Apple later denied the claims which saw some of the losses pare slightly. Big tech (FB, GOOGL, AMZN, AAPL) opened lower amid a US House panel probing antitrust behaviour; Netflix (NFLX) bucked the FAANG trend after a positive mention at Piper Jaffray. Financials were an outperforming sector given the steeper yield curve. Broadcom (AVGO) opened lower after missing Revenue estimates for Q3 and its FY guidance. Higher copper prices on trade truce optimism boosted Freeport-McMoRan (FCX). Progressive (PGR) underperformed after disappointing August figures. Altria (MO) dipped after reports Juul, which it owns a 35% stake in, had taken a large valuation cut in the secondary market. Tyson Foods (TSN) benefitted from China excluding pork from tariffs. PG&E (PCG) spiked higher after reaching a settlement for its wildfire insurance claims.

* FX WRAP:

EUR: It would be tempting and justified to suggest that the week boiled down to Thursday given the sheer scale of currency moves sparked by the ECB’s policy action, as President Draghi’s swansong (albeit not last meeting at the helm) was all and more than most expected, if not desired. Indeed, amidst obvious and subsequently vocalised GC dissent the Bank unleashed a multi-pronged salvo including all the various tools at its disposure and signalled in July, albeit not to the extent that it might have. To recap, the key depo rate was trimmed 10 bp, QE was restarted at a Eur 20 bn/month pace and forward guidance was radically reformed to an inflation rather than time contingency with further reinforcement via merging standard and unconventional policy to the common goal of headline, underlying and inflation expectations reaching robust convergence and stability around the target level. However, arguably the biggest change was the introduction of tiering that provides relief for banks that can benefit from NIRP exemptions of up to 6-fold on excess reserves, and also allows the ECB more scope to cut the depo further if needed. For the record, TLTRO3 terms were also relaxed and the maturities extended from 2 to 3 years, but banks are still due to make early repayments on previous loans so this may not be as pertinent overall. In short, the Euro posted lows for the day and week around 1.0928 before erasing all its losses and more then extending the sharp reversal on Friday, with Eur/Usd hitting 1.1109 at one stage, as ECB dissenters underscored a unanimous view revealed by Draghi that the onus if now on Governments and fiscal policy to supplement September’s extensive/open-ended stimulus package.

GBP: Although the single currency’s revival was impressive, Sterling is actually G10 top dog, with Cable continuing its rebound from early September ytd troughs (1.1959 discounting the so called ‘flash crash’ base) to 1.2495 before tailing off on the back of considerably better than expected UK data (GDP, ip, earnings and jobless rate) and less hard Brexit angst. In short, PM Johnson suffered a sixth defeat at the hands of Parliament and a 2nd in terms of a snap election, while his prorogation was ruled to be illegal by the Scottish High Court and will now be passed to the Supreme Court next Tuesday. Meanwhile, the Queen gave her seal on the anti-no deal bill that effectively means application for a further Article 50 extension if no accord is reached at the October 17-18 EU Summit and papers from Brussels suggest the bloc may be amenable to granting more time after October 31 if there is hope of clinching an agreement. On this note, some signs that the DUP could accept some form of alternative Irish backstop, but no guarantee, as Johnson heads for a meeting with Juncker on Monday.

USD: Aside from the pronounced moves at the tail end of the week, largely at the behest of the Euro and contagion elsewhere, the Greenback has been attuned to mostly improving developments and general risk sentiment surrounding US-China trade relations, as olive branches from Beijing were greeted in kind by Washington and President Trump personally via the delay of additional tariffs scheduled for October 1 to 15. Moreover, ongoing tech-level talks were upgraded and suitably productive such that an interim accord appears on the cards/in principle after more mid-status negotiations next week and the big guns get together early next month for the face-off that was aborted this month. However, the DXY carved out weekly highs and lows of 99.109 and 97.992 when dovetailing the Eur, with only limited upticks on upbeat US data/surveys in the form of PPI, some elements of CPI, retail sales and Michigan sentiment, as pre-FOMC positioning and another volley of Trump criticism of the Fed kept the Dollar on the defensive.

TRY/CNH: The Lira also saw whippy moves on CB impulses, albeit nowhere near as volatile as the Euro, with the CBRT exceeding expectations again when slashing rates by 325 bp. Turkish President Erdogan wanted more of course with a pro-Government paper teasing as much as 500 bp, but investors/markets appear content that rates are returning to normal as a sign of the economy overall and the fact that CPI unwound all and more of its ‘one-off’ spike, which the Central Bank acknowledged in the accompany statement via a more benign outlook compared to July. Similarly, the PBoC’s scaled RRR reductions that start from Monday and range from 50-100 bp have complemented the bullish Yuan reaction allied to the more constructive/less strained US-China trade situation.

AUD/NZD/CAD/JPY/CHF/XAU: Contrasting fortunes for the high-beta and traditional safe havens on fluctuating risk sentiment and specific or independent drivers, but the Aussie has been a decent net gain vs its US and NZ counterpart, while the Kiwi and Loonie have lagged/underperformed. Similarly, the Yen has suffered more from safe-haven unwinding and with the BoJ looming amidst sources saying further stimulus is a close call, while the Franc faces next week’s SNB policy review with less reason to anticipate a more aggressive response given the Euro’s snap-back and Gold has been relatively well bid on pull-backs through the Usd1500/oz level, for now at least.

* BREXIT: Overnight, the DUP reportedly agreed to Northern Ireland accepting some EU rules post Brexit as part of a deal to replace the backstop. Which was followed by comments from Party Leader Foster that the UK must leave EU as one nation. Another positive development, UK PM Johnson was urged by his cabinet allies to ask for a Brexit extension instead of disobeying the law and risk having a labour government. UK PM Johnson then stated there was an approximate shape of a deal to be done on Brexit, adding he is cautiously optimistic about a deal.  Elsewhere, reports suggested that an EU Diplomat did state that talks with UK European Advisor/Negotiator Frost were the best so far, albeit not yet the beginning of a solution.

13th September 2019

  • Of note for Big Tech (FB, GOOGL, AMZN, AAPL), WSJ reports that the FTC’s most pressing matter is to provide guidance, which can be used by lawmakers, on its ability to probe anti-competitive behaviour by tech Cos. Elsewhere, a US House Judiciary Panel has requested company records from Alphabet, Amazon, Apple and Facebook (FB) as part of an antitrust investigation. 

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has had its PT lowered at Goldman Sachs to USD 165 from USD 187, analyst Rod Hall cites the latest proposal to provide Apple TV+ at a discount on a one-year trial will be a 14% drag on EPS for FY20.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) – India has said that it will need to conduct its own checks, in addition to requiring all pilots to complete simulator training, before the 737 Max can fly again, adding that even if the FAA have it flying this year, it does not see it flying until next year.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) and The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) have announced a five-year partnership for innovative ways to provide content through Microsoft’s Azure cloud network.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has had a subpoena filed against it by Texas AG Ken Paxton which contains hundreds of questions and demands which seeks to gain the rationale behind acquiring several Cos for its Ad business, WSJ reports.
  • Biogen Inc. (BIIB) (Health Care/Biotechnology) and Eisai Co. (ESALY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) are to discontinue their Phase 3 studies of their Alzheimer’s treatment, elenbecestat, due to a safety review suggesting an unfavourable risk/benefit ratio.
  • Broadcom Inc. (AVGO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) Q3 19 (USD): adj. EPS 5.16 (exp. 5.12), Revenue 5.515bln (exp. 5.53bln). Affirms FY Revenue view 22.5bln (exp. 22.61bln). Believes demand has bottomed out in semiconductor solutions segment, but to remain at these levels due to current environment.
  • Celgene Corp. (CELG) (Health Care/Biotechnology) reported promising results from its Phase 3 study of its acute myeloid leukaemia treatment, CC-486.
  • Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) could have upside to its Q3 international subs, as according to Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson who cites Netflix and YouTube data models/analysis which sees in-line domestic subscriber growth but an above expected international figure.

S&P 500

  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) – Juul, which Altria has a 35% ownership stake in, is mulling a potential push back on the latest plan by the Trump administration to withdraw flavoured e-cigarettes from the market.
  • Baker Hughes (BHGE) (Energy/Oil & Gas Equipment & Services) has been indicted by a grand jury in Alaska due to toxic chemical releases at one of its construction sites.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt discounted again, but Dollar derives some retail therapy
content: No lasting respite for bonds as early US data reveals ongoing strength on the consumption side with another forecast beating sales update, while Gilts are also digesting more cautiously optimistic Brexit deal banter from the UK PM. Hence, 10 year benchmarks are heading back towards intraday lows or slipping to fresh session bases (131.32 for the UK contract), while the Buck is paring losses with the DXY reclaiming 98.000+ status, albeit tentatively ahead of business inventories and Michigan sentiment that round off the week.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are firmer this morning on positive US-China updates, though gains are relatively marginal
  • China State Council will exclude some agricultural products including soybeans and pork from additional tariffs on US goods
  • US President Trump said he would rather get a whole deal with China than an interim deal but suggested that he would consider an interim trade deal with China
  • In FX, Sterling shines on DUP comments while EUR continues to strengthen post-ECB, albeit off of best levels
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Import & Export prices Retail Sales & University of Michigan Sentiment (Prelim)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded higher as the positive tone rolled over from Wall St where the major indices edged mild gains and the DJIA notched a 7-day win streak with sentiment underpinned on the improving US-China trade climate and after the ECB announced a package of stimulus measures. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were higher throughout the majority of session although Australia later returned flat as the outperformance in industrials and financials was counterbalanced by weakness in the tech and mining sectors, while the Japanese benchmark cheered the recent currency weakness and eyed the 22k level. Hang Seng (+1.0%) conformed to the positive risk tone as the recent encouraging trade developments spurred hopes for a ceasefire in the US-China trade war with Chinese negotiators said to be making plans to boost purchases of US agricultural products and with US President Trump suggesting he could consider an interim deal with China. However, gains were restricted in Hong Kong amid the absence of the mainland due to the Mid-Autumn Festival holiday and ahead of a potential weekend of further clashes after the police banned a planned march for Sunday. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lower in an extension of the recent weakness to track the losses seen in global counterparts, with demand also sapped after a softer enhanced liquidity auction in the long-end and amid reports some BoJ members were said to believe JGB yields are close to a tipping point and would consider action with a move below -0.3%.

US President Trump said he would rather get a whole deal with China than an interim deal but suggested that he would consider an interim trade deal with China. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he is hopeful progress will be made in US-China talks and stated that Huawei is not a pawn in trade talks. (FT)

US administration officials are said to have debated removing or reducing some tariffs on China to ease trade tensions which potentially paves the way for a fresh ceasefire. (Newswires)

China State Council will exclude some agricultural products including soybeans and pork from additional tariffs on US goods, Xinhua reports. Prior to this, China’s Global Times Editor says that based on what he knows, "Chinese govt encourages Chinese companies to buy certain amount of US farm products, including soybeans and pork, which will also be exempted from additional tariffs. It is hoped the US side can keep goodwill reciprocity with China through practical actions.” (Twitter)

US

US President Trump said he will announce a tax-cut for the middle-income sometime next year. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson was urged by Cabinet allies to ask for a Brexit extension instead of disobeying the law and risk having a Labour government. (Telegraph)

DUP Leader Foster said the UK must leave the EU as one nation and that her party is keen for a sensible deal but not one that divides the internal market of UK. In separate reports, the DUP could agree to Northern Ireland accepting some EU rules post-Brexit as part of a deal to replace the backstop in which the party suggested privately it may drop its objection to regulatory checks in the Irish Sea in return for the EU to abandon insistence of Northern Ireland remain in Customs Union with EU and accept to fast track alternative arrangements. (Twitter/Times)

UK Government are reportedly preparing to increase the size of their Brexit negotiating team, with an understanding in Downing Street that if they cannot get an election then they need to secure a deal. (Times)

Group of MPs which successfully challenged the Government in the Scottish Court ruling over prorogation believe that the Scottish Judges have the power to send a letter to Brussels asking for an extension if PM Johnson does not, and want the Court to rule it will do so if necessary. (Telegraph)

Former Tory leadership rival Rory Stewart is being urged by some of the 21 rebels to stand against PM Johnson in his Uxbridge and South Ruislip constituency. (Newswires/The Sun)

German Economy Minister do not currently expect an economic downturn or pronounced recession, exports are moving sideways at the moment but economy supported by private and state consumption. (Newswires)

Italian Economy Minister says that there will be no more clashes with the EU, Eurozone needs to have more expansionary fiscal policy. (Newswires)

ECB's Knot (Hawk) says the ECB's measures are not in line with the economic situation, the Eurozone is growing at full capacity; says restarting QE is not the right instrument. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are modestly higher [EuroStoxx 50 +0.4%], following on from a similarly upbeat APAC session, in which sentiment was underpinned by optimism on the US/China trade front (US President Trump said he would consider an interim trade deal with China, while China appeared to recommence soybean purchases from the US) and following the ECB’s announcement of a package of stimulus measures. In terms of index performance, the FTSE 100 (is the laggard with Sterling strength weighing on exporters, although the index is somewhat underpinned with Credit Suisse now overweight in UK equities. Financials are the leading sector, aided by the recent rise in yields and curve steepening. On that note, according to JPM, Deutsche Bank (+3.4%) is set to benefit the most, with 10% relief (as a % of estimated 2020 profit before tax), although they do slightly lag the Eurostoxx banking index (+3.0%). Meanwhile, Materials are also higher, whilst the defensive utilities, consumer staples and health care sectors lag. In terms of individual movers; SSE (+0.9%) is up on the news that the Co. has agreed to sell its SSE Energy Services unit for GBP 500mln. Notable losers include Diageo (-3.3%), who are down after union strike threat relating to pay and Atlantia (-7.0%), who sunk on the news that Italian tax police are carrying

Boeing (BA) informed Spicejet that its 737 Max will be fit to fly by November, according to CNBC. (Newswires)

FX

GBP - The Pound continues to piggy-back Euro gains in post-ECB trade, but with the added incentive of no deal Brexit risk declining further amidst reports that the EU could be poised to offer the UK yet another Article 50 extension, while the DUP shows signs of flexibility on the Irish border backstop. Hence, Cable has reclaimed another big figure and extended its stellar rebound from 2019 lows on September 3 to 500+ pips at circa 1.2476 vs 1.1959, while Eur/Gbp has retreated towards 0.8900 again as the single currency hits resistance just above 1.1100 vs the Dollar.

EUR/CHF/AUD/JPY - All firmer against the Greenback, but as noted above Eur/Usd has faded after crossing the 1.1100 line and failing to sustain its recovery momentum to challenge the 50 DMA at 1.1130, while the Franc faces some psychological obstacles at 0.9850 having breached 0.9900 in the run up to next week’s FOMC and SNB Quarterly Policy review. Elsewhere, the Aussie remains capped below 0.6900 and the 100 DMA (0.6904), with Aud/Usd currently holding between 0.6877-60 and more technical levels spanning 0.6880-67 including the 55 DMA and the apex of a daily chart formation. The safe haven Yen has pared some losses against the backdrop of improving US-China trade relations as prospects of an interim accord forged at the upcoming mid-level meeting grow on the back of latest tariff exemptions from Beijing. Usd/Jpy has slipped back through 108.00 from around 108.27, while Usd/CNH has retraced further towards 7.0000 without PBoC prompting given China’s mid-Autumn festivities, to sub-7.0400 and not far from the 50 DMA (7.0193).

CAD/NZD/NOK/SEK - Marginal G10 laggards even though the DXY has dipped under 98.000 from just over 99.000 at one stage in the fleeting ECB aftermath on Thursday, with the Loonie unable to retrieve 1.3200 against the backdrop of soggy crude prices and Kiwi pivoting 0.6400 as the Aud/Nzd cross finally breaks above 1.0700 and with conviction to just shy of 1.0750. Next up for the Kiwi, Westpac’s Q3 consumer survey after scant improvement in the manufacturing PMI overnight (still some way below 50) and house sales slumping in August. In Scandinavia, the Crowns are narrowly mixed after revised Q2 Swedish GDP data and amidst the aforementioned dip in oil, with Eur/Nok elevated within 9.9150-9600 range vs Eur/Sek closer to the middle of 10.6290-6775 parameters.

Notable FX Expiries (NY Cut):

- EUR/USD: 1.1000 (2.5BLN), 1.1050-55 (1.5BLN), 1.1100 (611M), 1.1150 (700M)

FIXED

Selling upticks is still proving profitable for those chancing their arm, but UK debt appears to be front-running the increasingly bearish moves with Gilts just off another fresh Liffe low of 131.50 amidst more headlines raising the subject of an even longer Brexit extension rather than the spectre of a no deal Halloween nightmare. Meanwhile, Bunds are clinging to 173.00 (just) and US Treasuries are holding just off overnight session troughs with the curve a tad steeper again in the run up to retail sales and the first look at conditions/sentiment for the current month via Michigan sentiment.Selling upticks is still proving profitable for those chancing their arm, but UK debt appears to be front-running the increasingly bearish moves with Gilts just off another fresh Liffe low of 131.50 amidst more headlines raising the subject of an even longer Brexit extension rather than the spectre of a no deal Halloween nightmare. Meanwhile, Bunds are clinging to 173.00 (just) and US Treasuries are holding just off overnight session troughs with the curve a tad steeper again in the run up to retail sales and the first look at conditions/sentiment for the current month via Michigan sentiment.

COMMODITIES

Choppy trade in the oil complex, albeit prices remain within yesterday’s ranges with WTI and Brent futures around 55.0/bbl above 60/bbl respectively. Looking at weekly performance, both benchmarks are poised to end the week in the red, with the the former closer to the bottom of the weekly range (USD 54-58.73/bbl) whilst the latter showed a similar performance within a USD 58.94-63.74/bbl weekly parameter. Over the week, EIA and OPEC downgraded their respective global oil demand forecasts for 2019 and 2020 whilst IEA maintain its forecast. Meanwhile, the JMMC saw little by way of major decision, although the energy ministers reportedly “unanimously” agreed to fully comply with the OPEC+ supply pact, which may see 400k BPD crude outflow from the market, given the undercompliance from some producers. A full review of the current pact will take place in December. Elsewhere, gold prices are on the rise as the USD is weighed on by a firmer EUR and GBP. The yellow metal remains above the USD 1500/oz, having visited a weekly base at USD 1484/oz earlier in the week (vs. weekly high of 1524/oz). Copper prices are poised to notch another day of gains, largely aided by the receding Buck as prices move further north of 2.60/lb ahead of its 100 DMA at 2.66/lb.

Russian Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin says Russian oil output may start falling after 2021. (Newswires)

Smoke has been observed outside Equinor's (EQNR NO) Norwegian Sture oil terminal, an evacuation is underway; smoke is reported from the Dubai Harmony oil tanker., NTB. (Newswires)

Meanwhile, Bunds are clinging to 173.00 (just) and US Treasuries are holding just off overnight session troughs with the curve a tad steeper again in the run up to retail sales and the first look at conditions/sentiment for the current month via Michigan sentiment.

COMMODITIES

Choppy trade in the oil complex, albeit prices remain within yesterday’s ranges with WTI and Brent futures around 55.0/bbl above 60/bbl respectively. Looking at weekly performance, both benchmarks are poised to end the week in the red, with the the former closer to the bottom of the weekly range (USD 54-58.73/bbl) whilst the latter showed a similar performance within a USD 58.94-63.74/bbl weekly parameter. Over the week, EIA and OPEC downgraded their respective global oil demand forecasts for 2019 and 2020 whilst IEA maintain its forecast. Meanwhile, the JMMC saw little by way of major decision, although the energy ministers reportedly “unanimously” agreed to fully comply with the OPEC+ supply pact, which may see 400k BPD crude outflow from the market, given the undercompliance from some producers. A full review of the current pact will take place in December. Elsewhere, gold prices are on the rise as the USD is weighed on by a firmer EUR and GBP. The yellow metal remains above the USD 1500/oz, having visited a weekly base at USD 1484/oz earlier in the week (vs. weekly high of 1524/oz). Copper prices are poised to notch another day of gains, largely aided by the receding Buck as prices move further north of 2.60/lb ahead of its 100 DMA at 2.66/lb.

GBP

The Pound continues to piggy-back Euro gains in post-ECB trade, but with the added incentive of no deal Brexit risk declining further amidst reports that the EU could be poised to offer the UK yet another Article 50 extension, while the DUP shows signs of flexibility on the Irish border backstop. Hence, Cable has reclaimed another big figure and extended its stellar rebound from 2019 lows on September 3 to 500+ pips at circa 1.2476 vs 1.1959, while Eur/Gbp has retreated towards 0.8900 again as the single currency hits resistance just above 1.1100 vs the Dollar.

EUR/CHF/AUD/JPY

All firmer against the Greenback, but as noted above Eur/Usd has faded after crossing the 1.1100 line and failing to sustain its recovery momentum to challenge the 50 DMA at 1.1130, while the Franc faces some psychological obstacles at 0.9850 having breached 0.9900 in the run up to next week’s FOMC and SNB Quarterly Policy review. Elsewhere, the Aussie remains capped below 0.6900 and the 100 DMA (0.6904), with Aud/Usd currently holding between 0.6877-60 and more technical levels spanning 0.6880-67 including the 55 DMA and the apex of a daily chart formation. The safe haven Yen has pared some losses against the backdrop of improving US-China trade relations as prospects of an interim accord forged at the upcoming mid-level meeting grow on the back of latest tariff exemptions from Beijing. Usd/Jpy has slipped back through 108.00 from around 108.27, while Usd/CNH has retraced further towards 7.0000 without PBoC prompting given China’s mid-Autumn festivities, to sub-7.0400 and not far from the 50 DMA (7.0193).

CAD/NZD/NOK/SEK 

Marginal G10 laggards even though the DXY has dipped under 98.000 from just over 99.000 at one stage in the fleeting ECB aftermath on Thursday, with the Loonie unable to retrieve 1.3200 against the backdrop of soggy crude prices and Kiwi pivoting 0.6400 as the Aud/Nzd cross finally breaks above 1.0700 and with conviction to just shy of 1.0750. Next up for the Kiwi, Westpac’s Q3 consumer survey after scant improvement in the manufacturing PMI overnight (still some way below 50) and house sales slumping in August. In Scandinavia, the Crowns are narrowly mixed after revised Q2 Swedish GDP data and amidst the aforementioned dip in oil, with Eur/Nok elevated within 9.9150-9600 range vs Eur/Sek closer to the middle of 10.6290-6775 parameters.

Back to Liffe, where Short Sterling contracts are also reeling again with the strip down 1.5-8.5 ticks at one stage, but now off worst levels ahead of a speech from BoE’s Cunliffe that in theory should avoid any live monetary policy or economic content so close to next week’s MPC meeting.

content: The big ECB bazooka backfire continues as the core Eurozone bond and counterparts extend their retracement from initial post-policy easing highs, with Bunds testing support ahead of 173.00 after dipping below a downside chart level from early August around 173.16 to a 173.08 base vs Thursday’s 173.93 close. content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded higher as the positive tone rolled over from Wall St where the major indices edged mild gains and the DJIA notched a 7-day win streak with sentiment underpinned on the improving US-China trade climate and after the ECB announced a package of stimulus measures. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) were higher throughout the majority of session although Australia later returned flat as the outperformance in industrials and financials was counterbalanced by weakness in the tech and mining sectors, while the Japanese benchmark cheered the recent currency weakness and eyed the 22k level. Hang Seng (+0.2%) conformed to the positive risk tone as the recent encouraging trade developments spurred hopes for a ceasefire in the US-China trade war with Chinese negotiators said to be making plans to boost purchases of US agricultural products and with US President Trump suggesting he could consider an interim deal with China. However, gains were restricted in Hong Kong amid the absence of the mainland due to the Mid-Autumn Festival holiday and ahead of a potential weekend of further clashes after the police banned a planned march for Sunday.

FTSE 100

(Times/Guardian)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded higher as the positive tone rolled over from Wall St where the major indices edged mild gains amidst the improving trade climate
  • US President Trump said he would rather get a whole deal with China than an interim deal but suggested that he would consider an interim trade deal with China
  • DUP could agree to Northern Ireland accepting some EU rules post-Brexit as part of a deal to replace the Irish Backstop
  • DXY is essentially flat heading into the week’s end on a quiet session ahead after yesterday’s ECB and US CPI
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Import & Export prices, University of Michigan Sentiment (Prelim) and BoE’s Cunliffe

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded higher as the positive tone rolled over from Wall St where the major indices edged mild gains and the DJIA notched a 7-day win streak with sentiment underpinned on the improving US-China trade climate and after the ECB announced a package of stimulus measures. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) were higher throughout the majority of session although Australia later returned flat as the outperformance in industrials and financials was counterbalanced by weakness in the tech and mining sectors, while the Japanese benchmark cheered the recent currency weakness and eyed the 22k level. Hang Seng (+0.2%) conformed to the positive risk tone as the recent encouraging trade developments spurred hopes for a ceasefire in the US-China trade war with Chinese negotiators said to be making plans to boost purchases of US agricultural products and with US President Trump suggesting he could consider an interim deal with China. However, gains were restricted in Hong Kong amid the absence of the mainland due to the Mid-Autumn Festival holiday and ahead of a potential weekend of further clashes after the police banned a planned march for Sunday. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lower in an extension of the recent weakness to track the losses seen in global counterparts, with demand also sapped after a softer enhanced liquidity auction in the long-end and amid reports some BoJ members were said to believe JGB yields are close to a tipping point and would consider action with a move below -0.3%.

US President Trump said he would rather get a whole deal with China than an interim deal but suggested that he would consider an interim trade deal with China. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he is hopeful progress will be made in US-China talks and stated that Huawei is not a pawn in trade talks. There were also separate comments from US Presidential Trade Advisor Pilsbury that President Trump could do a quick deal with China but doesn’t want a quick deal and instead wants the right deal, while he added that Trump warned if China waits 16 months for a deal, it will be harder to get. (Newswires/Fox)

US administration officials are said to have debated removing or reducing some tariffs on China to ease trade tensions which potentially paves the way for a fresh ceasefire. There were also separate reports that President Trump's advisors are said to be rushing to find an escape from tariff increases in the coming months and are trying to bring back the previous terms negotiated in May, according to a source. (FT/Politico)

Chinese importers bought 600k tonnes of US soybeans for October to December shipment from the Pacific North West, according to traders. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson was urged by Cabinet allies to ask for a Brexit extension instead of disobeying the law and risk having a Labour government. (Telegraph)

UK House Speaker Bercow warned PM Johnson that parliament will impose more "draconian" measures if he attempts to bypass the law ruling out a no deal next month, according to Daily Mail's Political Editor. (Twitter)

DUP Leader Foster said the UK must leave the EU as one nation and that her party is keen for a sensible deal but not one that divides the internal market of UK. In separate reports, the DUP could agree to Northern Ireland accepting some EU rules post-Brexit as part of a deal to replace the backstop in which the party suggested privately it may drop its objection to regulatory checks in the Irish Sea in return for the EU to abandon insistence of Northern Ireland remain in Customs Union with EU and accept to fast track alternative arrangements. (Twitter/Times)

UK Government are reportedly preparing to increase the size of their Brexit negotiating team, with an understanding in Downing Street that if they cannot get an election then they need to secure a deal. (Times)

Group of MPs which successfully challenged the Government in the Scottish Court ruling over prorogation believe that the Scottish Judges have the power to send a letter to Brussels asking for an extension if PM Johnson does not, and want the Court to rule it will do so if necessary. (Telegraph)

Former Tory leadership rival Rory Stewart is being urged by some of the 21 rebels to stand against PM Johnson in his Uxbridge and South Ruislip constituency. (Newswires/The Sun)

French, German, Dutch, Austrian and Estonian were among the ECB Governors which opposed the QE resumption which passed via a narrow majority, according to ECB sources. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was flat after the recent mixed US CPI data and with trade mostly uneventful this week aside from the ECB-induced turbulence, while markets look ahead to US Retail Sales data later and more importantly, next week’s FOMC. EUR/USD stabilized from the whipsawing seen in the aftermath of the ECB meeting. GBP/USD also lacked direction amid continued Brexit uncertainty with PM Johnson said to have been urged by Cabinet allies to ask for a Brexit extension and with the EU preparing to grant the UK a third delay to Brexit according to a leaked resolution, although officials in Brussels were said to be pessimistic regarding an imminent breakthrough. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slightly extended on gains amid the positive risk tone and CNH continued to benefit from the improved trade environment, while antipodeans were lacklustre after the prior day’s losses and amid a sparse overnight calendar. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures languished below the USD 55.00/bbl level after outside hopes of an immediate extended production cuts at the OPEC+ JMMC meeting failed to materialise. Elsewhere, gold traded flat amid an uneventful greenback but remained in proximity for another attempt on the USD 1500/oz level, while copper was supported by the positive risk appetite although gains were limited by the absence of its biggest purchaser China.

 

US police official said that the protests at the Houston shipping port could be "prolonged". (Newswires) 

 

US

The TPLEX, and EGBs, were whipped about in the wake of the ECB. The initial announcement of fresh open-ended QE spiked futures; however, as participants read between the lines of the fresh stimulus, bonds pared reversed their initial move, with some desks attributing little detail of whether the ECB would add more asset classes to its QE programme. At settlement, yields were higher by approximately 6bps across the entire Treasury curve. US T-notes (z9) settled 15 ticks lower at 129-14.

US President Trump said he will announce a tax-cut for the middle-income sometime next year. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade higher amid the improved US-China trade climate and following ECB's stimulus package
content:
Asia equity markets trade higher as the positive tone rolls over from Wall St where all major indices edged mild gains and the DJIA notched a 7-day win streak with sentiment underpinned on the improving US-China trade climate and after the ECB announced a package of stimulus measures. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) are higher with industrials and financials leading the gains in Australia but with upside in the broader market capped by weakness in the tech and mining sectors, while the Japanese benchmark cheers the recent currency weakness as it homes in on the 22k level. Hang Seng (+0.2%) conforms to the positive risk tone as the recent encouraging trade developments spurs hopes for a ceasefire in the US-China trade war with Chinese negotiators said to be making plans to boost purchases of US agricultural products and with US President Trump suggesting he could consider an interim deal with China. However, gains are restricted in Hong Kong amid the absence of mainland China due to the Mid-Autumn Festival holiday and ahead of a potential weekend of further clashes after the police banned a planned march for Sunday.

In FX markets, the DXY is flat after the recent mixed US CPI data and with the greenback mostly uneventful this week aside from the ECB-induced turbulence, while markets look ahead to US Retail Sales data later and more importantly, next week’s FOMC. EUR/USD stabilized from the whipsawing seen in the aftermath of the ECB meeting where the announcement of a stimulus package including 10bps Deposit Rate cut and resumption of QE at EUR 20bln/month initially pressured the single currency briefly below 1.1000, before staging an aggressive recovery given that markets were heavily one-sided and as some had hoped for a larger QE amount. GBP/USD also lacked direction amid continued Brexit uncertainty with PM Johnson said to have been urged by Cabinet allies to ask for a Brexit extension instead of disobey the law and with the EU preparing to grant the UK a third delay to Brexit according to a leaked resolution, although officials in Brussels were said to be pessimistic regarding an imminent breakthrough. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slightly extends on gains amid the positive risk tone and antipodeans are lacklustre after the prior day’s losses and amid a sparse overnight calendar.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they extend on the recent weakness and track the losses seen in global counterparts, with demand also sapped ahead of an enhanced liquidity auction and amid reports some BoJ members are said to believe that JGB yields are close to a tipping point and would consider action with a move below -0.3%.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: Mainland China is closed for holiday
content:
China Railway Group (390 HK) - Co. awarded USD 825mln contract for gold mine project in Solomon Islands. (Newswires)

China Southern Airlines (1055 HK) - Co. reports August traffic rose 8.6% Y/Y. (Newswires)

HKEX (388 HK) - Co. is said to be considering raising the cash portion of its bid for LSE (LSE LN). (FT)

Trade

US President Trump tweeted it is expected that China will be buying large amounts of US agricultural products. US President Trump also stated he would rather get a whole deal with China than an interim deal but suggested that he would consider an interim trade deal with China. (Newswires) (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump is prepared to keep tariffs on China and raise them if needed. (Newswires)

US administration officials are said to have debated removing or reducing some tariffs on China to ease trade tensions which potentially paves the way for a fresh ceasefire. There were also separate reports that President Trump's advisors are said to be rushing to find an escape from tariff increases in the coming months and are trying to bring back the previous terms negotiated in May, according to a source. (FT/Politico)

US Presidential Trade Advisor Pilsbury said President Trump could do a quick deal with China but doesn’t want a quick deal and instead wants the right deal, while he added that Trump made the case that if China waits 16 months for a deal, it will be harder to get. (Fox)

China Vice Premier Liu He confirmed China and US working-level officials will meet next week to discuss trade balance, market access and investors' protections. (Newswires)

China’s MOFCOM said Chinese firms have begun enquiring about prices for US farm purchases and they welcome the US good will gesture regarding the US-China trade dispute. MOFCOM stated that China and US are in communication regarding high-level discussions and the working teams will meet soon, while it added that China will roll-out supportive measures to stabilise trade at a time which is appropriate. (Newswires)

China is looking to narrow the trade negotiations with the US in a bid to break the deadlock with deputy-level Chinese trade officials planning to head to Washington next week to pave the way for the high-level meeting. Chinese negotiators are said to be making plans to boost purchases of US agricultural products, giving American companies greater access to China’s market and bolstering intellectual-property protections. (WSJ)

Chinese importers bought 600k tonnes of US soybeans for October to December shipment from the Pacific North West, according to traders. (Newswires)
